content.description:
Start on the low-angled rock at the base of Blipvert Wall and follow the orange painted hangers up the obvious crack to a ledge beneath the roof. Muster your roof-pulling power and then try to manage your exploding forearms (perhaps with a sneaky kneebar) as you quest up a finicky face to a heartbreaking finish.

The leftmost line of bolts on the face to the right of the crack (Max Headroom, trad, 5.10c)
14 draws, excluding anchors. Putting 60 cm alpine draws on the two bolts below the roof will help decrease rope drag later.

A long varied route that tests a climber’s versatility. Begins with hard to read face climbing followed by a solid rest and then technical crack climbing.  Tough clips, good foot work, and a couple finger locks get you through the middle section.  Depump at the roof and pull a couple powerful moves until a large rest.  The route crux comes at the very end. Skipping the last clip eases the grade and only extends the fall a bit.   



To the right of Apricot Jam.  Follows the second crack line through the prominent roof.  

Bolts

Starts on positive but smooth holds on the low angled base.  Some techy moves bring you to a beautiful finger crack up high. This thing climbs like a granite crack climb, but its never desperate due to good feet.  Be sure to save some juice for the final pumpy moves through the roof. 

Left of the prominent crack (Max headroom)in the middle of the wall. 
13 bolts. Long slings are a good idea for some bolts in the middle of the climb.

A fun warm-up for the rest of the stuff here.

This route is  on the south face of Blipvert, just below the east wall of Fern Gully. The left-most climb on this face.
Bolted all the way up.

Located on the west face of Blipvert Tower, this is a newer variation on some existing routes.  It takes the line of red painted bolts up a steep and sustained technical face, along a right-trending seam, and then through a burly series of overlaps.  At almost 35m long and with no rests in the last two thirds, this is a real pump fest.

18 draws! Bolted anchor (and last few bolts up the arete) shared with Green Machine.
Second bolt line from the right. Splits at the top and heads right.

A crack with increasingly good climbing.

The crack between Browbeaten and Apricot Jam. Starts up the obvious featured ramp.
Gear.

Although west-facing, Blipvert is in a fairly tight gully so keeps shade longer in the morning than other walls facing the same direction. This area has seen some development in the last half decade, and is now home to a few hard, long sport routes.
